mxCell.value: I've renamed my budget!

<<Accounts>>

You're currently in your Accounts screen. We will be here for a while as I give you a tour and help you set up your account.
move_to: budget_name

<<Accounts>>

Looking good, [[user_first_name]]! It's time to start adding your accounts.
Account Tour and Setup Process

<<Accounts>>

To add your account:

1. Click "Create Local Account" and give it a name.
2. Click the down arrow next to 'Select a Type' and choose 'For Budget: Checking'.
3. Enter the current balance of that account.
4. Click 'Create'

<<Accounts>>

Great, now that you've got your balance. 

Select + Add Account

<<Accounts>>

For this step, you'll need to log into your bank account and see the current balance. 

Remember, if you are an entrepreneur and are managing personal and business finances separately, we'll be focusing on your personal budget for this tour.

After you've got that info, come on back to me!
move_to: add_account
Budget Summary and Tour Overview

Alrighty, let's kickstart this budgeting party!

 Please click on the Budget button if you aren't already on the Budget screen.

<<Budget>>

I hate to keep you on the edge of your seat, but before setting up your budget or spending plan, I'm going to give you a tour of your budget screen. 

Here, you'll find the current month displayed and options to navigate to previous and future months.

<<Budget>>

 You can view one month at a time or several months at a time.
Depending on your browser zoom level, you can select to view up to six months at a time. 

Click on the calendar icons to give them a try.
move_to: calendar_icons

<<Budget>>

 Let's change the view so you can see a different set of months using the purple selection.
move_to: months_band
I see it.

<<Budget>>

Below the current month, there are several pieces of information and an amount labeled "To Budget."
move_to: budget_header
Got it!

<<Budget>>

While you're getting to know MyBudgetCoach, just focus on the amount to budget for now.

<<Budget>>

Click on the purple number to see some options for the 'To Budget' amount. It's meant to be flexible, so there are multiple ways to move money around your budget.

<<Budget>>

Whew, that's a lot of information! Here's a cute puppy to help break the tension. Remember, I'm always here to help you along the way!

Let's keep moving!
Budget Table Overview

<<Budget>>

This is your budget table, which is basically a digital cash envelope system!.

<<Budget>>

Next up is the Spent column. Here, you'll see exactly how much you've spent from your budgeted amount.

<<Budget>>

The last column is the Balance column. This column shows how much you have left to spend.

If the balance is black: that's your available amount.
 
If the balance is negative and red: it means you've overspent in this category.

<<Budget>>
 
Managing overspending starts with awareness. You might find that you're overspending in certain categories because you didn't budget for them, or you're spending in areas you forgot about.

<<Budget>>

To the right of the header 'Category' at the top of the Budget Table, select the three dots. 

This gives you visual options. You can show and hide hidden categories and collapse or expand Category Groups.

<<Budget>>

When you hover over a row, an arrow appears. 

The rows in 'Grey' that have bold text are called 'Category Groups.' The arrow in a Category Group row has options to add a category in this group, hide it, rename it or delete it.

<<Budget>>

Can I just take a moment to commend you for sticking it out this far? 

Budgeting can be intimidating, but you're doing an amazing job. It may seem like a lot of work now, but once the foundation is set, it will get easier and be totally worth it in the end.
Add Transaction

<<Accounts>>

Note: For checking account transactions, adding payments will DECREASE the balance and adding deposits will INCREASE the balance.

You can think of it like your bank account: making deposits to your account increases the balance while making payments from your account decreases the balance.
Got it!

<<Accounts>>

Let's practice adding a new transaction using a sample bill.

1. Click "+ Add New"  
2. Select today's date.
move_to: add_new_button

<<Accounts>>

For the category, select "Bills."

<<Accounts>>

Did you notice the check mark next to the transaction? It's greyed out for now because new transactions appear as uncleared until you clear them.

Finish this transaction by selecting the check mark to turn it green.

<<Accounts>>

Yay, you've entered your first transaction! Gold stars for you. 🌟🌟

Now take a look at the account balance—it now reflects a decrease of $100.
move_to: account_balance

<<Accounts>>

Okay, let's delete this pretend transaction. 

1. Hover on the left side of the date to un-hide the box. 
2. Select the box to select the transaction.

<<Accounts>>

You've made it to the end our Account Tour and Set up. You are doing so well, [[user_first_name]]!

Here's an overview of what we have accomplished and what's coming up next:

1. Account Tour & Set Up
2. Adding Transactions 
3. Budget Tour & Setup
4. Budgeting Skills

%3CmxGraphModel%3E%3Croot%3E%3CmxCell%20id%3D%220%22%2F%3E%3CmxCell%20id%3D%221%22%20parent%3D%220%22%2F%3E%3CmxCell%20id%3D%222%22%20value%3D%22%26amp%3Blt%3B%26amp%3Blt%3BAccounts%26amp%3Bgt%3B%26amp%3Bgt%3B%26lt%3Bbr%26gt%3B%26lt%3Bbr%26gt%3BYou've%20made%20it%20to%20the%20end%20our%20Account%20You%20are%20doing%20so%20good%2C%20%5B%5Buser_first_name%5D%5D!%22%20style%3D%22rounded%3D0%3BwhiteSpace%3Dwrap%3Bhtml%3D1%3BfillColor%3D%23d5e8d4%3BstrokeColor%3D%2382b366%3BfontStyle%3D0%22%20vertex%3D%221%22%20parent%3D%221%22%3E%3CmxGeometry%20x%3D%224689.999999999999%22%20y%3D%221206%22%20width%3D%22190%22%20height%3D%2290%22%20as%3D%22geometry%22%2F%3E%3C%2FmxCell%3E%3C%2Froot%3E%3C%2FmxGraphModel%3E

<<Accounts>>

3. To the right-hand side of the search box, select the purple text with '1 transaction' to view your options.

4. We want to remove the pretend transaction, so select 'Delete' to remove it.

<<Accounts>>

You are now interacting with my avatar, [[user_first_name]]. While direct chatting with my avatar isn't available, you can still interact and get guided assistance through our structured conversations.

Remember, it's okay to take things at your own pace. You can easily reset your progress, go back to previous steps to review, or take a break whenever you need.

<<Accounts>>

If you ever feel stuck or just need a little extra help, don’t hesitate to reach out. You can use the Schedule Video Call button on the left-hand side to book a support call with me.
move_to: zoom_link

<<Accounts>>

Here's what we'll be covering:

1. Account Tour & Set up
2. Adding Transactions 
3. Budget Tour & Set up
4. Budgeting Skills

Database - can keep responses and reference later on; not all questions need the database capture. The second line of the response selected is the database code. If not planning to reference answer later or drive flow based on response in another section, don't need second line.

<<Accounts>> / <<Budget>>

This aligns the avatar with which screen the user should be on. If a user goes to the Budget at a step where the avatar flow has <<Accounts>>, or if the user goes to an Account while the avatar is on Budget, the user will see the following message:

 Please navigate to the Accounts {Budget} to continue our conversation (please select an account).

Please Note: There needs to be a blank line between the reference to Accounts/Budget and the text shown in the avatar window.
Trusting Your Numbers

One of the complexities for users with a zero-based budgeting software is the due diligence to ensure the account balances in MyBudgetCoach match the account balances in the financial institution. 

A difficult part of having the accounts match is ensuring the starting balance set by the user at the time the accounts are added are accurate. For checking accounts, some banks include pending transactions in the Current Balance. If the starting balance includes pending transactions, then when the transactions are added, they will be double counted. For credit cards, the Current Balance doesn't include pending transactions, so this is not an issue. 

Coach can consider consulting Coach Trainers to add a flow for verifying starting balance.
<font style="font-size: 14px;">...one last thing before I leave you to your budgeting...</font>
Of course

I submitted the form

<font style="font-size: 12px;">Thanks so much! Happy budgeting, [[user_first_name]]!</font>
User Survey after Tutorial
Budget Skills

OMGEEE, [[user_first_name]]!! You made it. I'm so proud of you. Look at all you've accomplished:

1. Account Tour & Setup
2. Adding Transactions 
3. Budget Tour & Setup
4. Budgeting Skills

I hope you had as much fun as I did.

Thank you again for choosing me as your coach. It has been a pleasure.

As a reminder, I am still available to you at any time as you move forward with your budgeting journey.

Just click that 'Schedule a Video call' link and find a day and time that works best for you!
Link to giphy: https://giphy.com/gifs/HannahWitton-hannah-witton-tBn5FJVUdeMarcl3gQ
I'm ready!

Hey [[user_first_name]]! I'm so glad you've chosen MyBudgetCoach to help manage your spending. You've picked me, Kayla, to be your personal budgeting coach, and I can't wait to get started with you! 😊

%3CmxGraphModel%3E%3Croot%3E%3CmxCell%20id%3D%220%22%2F%3E%3CmxCell%20id%3D%221%22%20parent%3D%220%22%2F%3E%3CmxCell%20id%3D%222%22%20value%3D%22%26amp%3Blt%3B%26amp%3Blt%3BBudget%26amp%3Bgt%3B%26amp%3Bgt%3B%26lt%3Bbr%26gt%3B%26lt%3Bbr%26gt%3BI%20recommend%20keeping%20your%20budget%20categories%20as%20simple%20as%20possible%20to%20start.%20You%20can%20always%20expand%20later%20once%20you%20get%20to%20know%20the%20platform%20better.%22%20style%3D%22rounded%3D0%3BwhiteSpace%3Dwrap%3Bhtml%3D1%3BfillColor%3D%23d5e8d4%3BstrokeColor%3D%2382b366%3BfontStyle%3D0%22%20vertex%3D%221%22%20parent%3D%221%22%3E%3CmxGeometry%20x%3D%22210.5%22%20y%3D%222897%22%20width%3D%22203.5%22%20height%3D%22103%22%20as%3D%22geometry%22%2F%3E%3C%2FmxCell%3E%3C%2Froot%3E%3C%2FmxGraphModel%3E
Budget Setup

You as the Coach can do as much or as little as you would like for the user. For example, if you just want to add a handful of categories, or walk them through how to edit and add themselves, that is fine. Alternatively, you could have the system build an entire budget with defined groups, and categories, so when they select the button before the template is built, it automatically updates.

Some coaches have built the table in phases, others offer the option of just groups, and the user adds categories, or the user adds everything. Full discretion to the coach!

<<Budget>>

Voila! You'll notice your budget table has been automatically updated.
I remember.

<<Budget>>

Do you remember when I mentioned that there are different ways to move money within MBC?

Here are two different ways:

1. Select the 'To Budget' number 
2. Enter amount into Budgeted column

<<Budget>>

Here is a tip on prioritizing budgeting dollars so all dollars are budgeted:

If you are starting in the middle or end of the month, do not use your budget for dollars already spent or that you don't need. 

For example, don't budget your entire month of monthly expenses if you only have 10 days left in the month.

<<Budget>>

If you see a negative red number in the balance column, MBC is letting you know that you have overspent in that category.
Don't Edit - Keep link and keep text
This is the end of the introduction conversation. A user can reset the conversation under the Manage Coach section.

<<Accounts>>

First things first, are you an entrepreneur or freelancer?

<<Accounts>>

Got it. Personal finances it is!

<<Accounts>>

That's great! You can create multiple budgets within MyBudgetCoach. We'll start with optimizing your personal finances first.
Let's go!

<<Accounts>>

Ok, [[user_first_name]]. Let's move on to adding a transaction to your checking account.

What kind of device?

Consider asking a user what type of device they are using. If using a computer, the current language for how to access options works. If using a tablet, somethings are different (tap versus hover; double click versus single click...). Can utilize the IF syntax to adjust the response in a box where overviewing how to use software dependent on the device the user has.

Buttons default to 'Next' if no text is added on line. Button text can be short, or long (even two sentences) and include emojis. If have multiple lines due to a question, can program button text for each line.
Consider having a question to create a break for the user. Could also reference the earlier list of steps to complete, and show progress by crossing out those pieces that are done.
Additional Conversations
Simple FIN

MyBudgetCoach has a direct import option. A coach can either walk through in detail how to complete this, or they can create a separate conversation for if a user to click through at a later point if interested.

Accounts can be linked at any time, so if added manually, can then link for direct import later on.

Linking direct import immediately can be helpful as SimpleFIN's connection will automatically set the starting balance. But the process takes some time and for a new user, they may want to make progress on the software itself and not spend 10-15 minutes just setting up direct import. 

Could always recommend they delete prior accounts, and add new ones once SimpleFIN is linked. This first budget is just a test to get started. Set up real budget with your actual accounts and setting up.

<<Accounts>>

 Let's continue our tour of the Account screen.

There are just a few more functions I want to point out to you.

<<Accounts>>

The 'Import' button allows you to upload an export of transactions from your bank.

This may be handy if you have a lot of transactions you need to enter when updating your budget.
It's deleted!
move_to: import_button

<<Accounts>>

The 'Filter' button allows you to filter down the transactions you are viewing by certain criteria (date, payee, category, etc..
move_to: filter_button

<<Accounts>>

The 'Undo' and 'Redo' buttons are helpful tools when you are working in this Account screen.

You can also undo or redo by using keyboard shortcuts. 
For Mac users: Use Command + Z  to undo and Command + Y will redo
For Window users: Ctrl + Z will undo and Ctrl + Y will redo

<<Accounts>>

This is the 'Search' bar. As you type, whether text or numbers, the list of transactions will dynamically filter down based on criteria entered.
move_to: search_bar

<<Accounts>>

This is the 'Split/Toggle' button. 

If you happen to have split transactions, this button will expand or collapse those transactions from view.
move_to: split_toggle_button

<<Accounts>>

These three dots, also known as the 'more' button, shows additional options.

Go ahead and click on the dots to see all of the available options.
move_to: more_button
Coach can decide how much explanation they want to provide for each of these. Reconciliation for example can be a complex discussion.

<<Accounts>>

Type "Cell Phone Company" as your Payee.
move_to: select_payee
move_to: select_category

<<Accounts>>

Now, enter $100 in the Payment field.
move_to: payment_input

<<Accounts>>

Click "Add" to enter the transaction. 

Note: you can select "Cancel" to get out of adding transactions.
move_to: cleared_status_icon
move_to: save_transaction
move_to: months_band
move_to: budget_table
move_to: spent_column
move_to: balance_column

<<Budget>>

The rows below a Category Group row (not shaded grey and not bolded text) are called Categories. 

When you hover over a Category row, the arrow that appears gives you the option to Hide, Rename, and Delete that Category.

<<Budget>>

Below the categories is the 'Income' Section.

<<Budget>>

The Income row is the total amount of deposits to a checking or savings account in a month. 

The Starting Balances row is calculated your first month, but then remains $0 each month after that. You can 'Hide' this category if you choose after your first month.
move_to: received_column

<<Budget>>

Also when you hover over a Category row, a small paper icon appears to the right of the arrow. If you click on the paper icon, it will open up a note box.

 This can be used to capture helpful information about that category. For example, the amount you intend to budget each month, or when it is due, if not due monthly.

<<Budget>>

When you hover over the month at the top of the budget summary, two up arrows are shown to the left. Selecting this will collapse the budget summary view to only show the 'To Budget' amount.

You can expand it again by hovering over the month and selecting the two down arrows to the left of the month.

<<Budget>>

To the right of the month there are three vertical dots.

Selecting this shows additional options that can budget dollars to all your categories in one click.

<<Budget>>

These options include:

1. Copy last month's budget
2. Set budgets to zero
3. Set budgets to 3-month average

Cool, right?
highlight: budget_more_button

All boxes don't need to have <<Accounts>> or <<Budget>>. If you remove this, that means the user can be in either screen and the avatar will continue. This can help with transitions from one section to another.

<<Budget>>

You've been patiently waiting, and the time has come for us to set up your budget!

<<Budget>>

Great job on understanding how to use the Budget! Before we wrap-up, there is one topic I did promise that I'd bring up again. Credit Cards!
move_to: selected_transactions_button

<<Accounts>>

Just a heads up! Scheduling a one-on-one support call with me does come with an additional fee. This ensures that I can provide you with personalized attention and support as needed.
I keep them separate
I combine everything

<<Accounts>>

Exciting! I'd love to know how you currently manage your finances. Do you keep your business and personal finances separate, or do you combine everything together?

<<Accounts>>

That's ok, but I highly suggest you separate the two. Feel free to book a call to get support with this.
Ready to proceed!

<<Accounts>>

You'll notice that you are presented with three options to connect your account. 

If you would like your transactions to sync automatically, MyBudgetCoach has partnered with GoCardless (for European banks) and SimpleFIN (for North American banks). 

These are great options if you do not want to manually input your transactions; however, they do require an additional small fee.

<<Accounts>>

For your actual transactions, I recommend keeping the check mark uncleared (greyed out) until they clear your bank account.

In other words, any pending transactions or payments that have not been processed by your bank should show as uncleared in MyBudgetCoach until they are no longer pending.

<<Accounts>>

If you need to take a break before we jump into our budgeting tour, now would be a great time to do so.

And don't worry, you can always come back and pick up where you left off.
Yes, I have used this budgeting method before!
What are you talking about, Kayla?
I've heard of it but could learn more about it.
Are you familiar with the cash envelope system?

<<Budget>>

Basically, you create categories relevant to your life and goals and budget your dollars accordingly.

Imagine you have $500 in your hand right now and you want to plan for how you are going to spend that $500.

<<Budget>>

Perfect! Then you're ahead of the game.

Managing your money through (digital) envelopes can really help you stay disciplined with your spending.
Yup, makes sense!
Uhhh.I still don't understand.
Does this make sense?

<<Budget>>

Great! I'm glad it makes sense. 
The cash envelope system is a simple way to see exactly where your money is going and make sure you don't run out too fast. With MyBudgetCoach we are doing this digitally.

<<Budget>>

No worries! Let me break it down using a real world example. The cash envelope system works like this:

I have several envelopes, each labeled with different spending categories. 

One of my envelopes is named Coffee Trips, and every time I get some income, I put $5.00 into my Coffee Trips envelope. 

This allows me to grab some cash(or digital cash) from that envelope whenever I take my coffee trips without guilt or worry about whether I have to forgo something else to afford it.

<<Budget>>

Let's keep going, and put our focus back on the budget table.
move_to: budget_table

<<Budget>>

Now that you have your budget set up, you're ready to learn how to go about budgeting your dollars and give every dollar a job!

<<Budget>>

Here's an overview of what we have accomplished and what's coming up next:

1. Account Tour & Setup
2. Adding Transactions 
3. Budget Tour & Setup
4. Budgeting Skills

<<Budget>>

I recommend keeping your budget category groups and categories as simple as possible to start. 

You can always expand later once you become more familiar with the platform and your spending habits.
I'm ready!

<<Budget>>

To give you a start in the right direction, I'm going to provide you with a template. Once you click the 'I'm ready!' button, magic will happen.

Are you ready for it?
I need some help with my budget table!

<<Budget>>

Take some time to update the categories under the category groups for your monthly bills and expenses and add new ones as needed. 

Adjust the names, amounts and due dates to reflect your actual situation accurately.

Also, feel free to add additional category groups.

<<Budget>>

I love to hear that! 

Well, right now would be a great time to take a break after how hard you've worked on your budget table.
Tell user about saving in these envelopes each month

<<Budget>>

You may be wondering what the difference between monthly expenses and monthly bills is. Let me explain.

<<Budget>>

Bills are your regular, fixed payments you have to make each month on a set date, like your rent or your phone bill. The cost stays pretty much the same every month.

Expenses are everything else you spend money on regularly, like groceries, eating out, or going to the movies, that change from month to month.

<<Budget>>

You now have a category group for your monthly bills, your monthly expenses and your savings contributions.

I highly recommend contributing to your savings account(s) as often as you can even if you can only save as little as $5 at a time.
I'm feeling good and ready to move on to budget skills!
How did it go?

<<Budget>>

No worries! Take a break, have.a drink and come on back with some fresh eyes. 

If you're still feeling overwhelmed or stuck, you can book a call with me so we can get you moving again.

<<Budget>>


I showed you option 1 earlier, but here's a refresher. 

Once you select the purple 'To Budget' number, click on 'Move to a Category' and you will have the option to 
transfer a certain amount of money to one of your categories.

<<Budget>>


Here is option 2: Enter amount into Budgeted column

I find this option to be simpler. You do this by entering a dollar amount directly on your budget table under the budgeted column next to your chosen category.
move_to: budget_header

<<Budget>>


One way is to click on the 'Move to a Category' option. This allows you to transfer a certain amount of money to one of your categories.

<<Accounts>>

Note: If you currently have a savings account(s), you do NOT need to add them. 

We will be creating a category for savings accounts later.
Yes, tell me more!

<<Accounts>>

Hold tight for now, and at the end of our tour and set ups, I will guide you on how to find the credit card conversation that will walk you through the process of adding credit cards.
No, but I do have credit card balances.
I don't use credit cards!
Are you interested in adding your credit card accounts?

<<Accounts>>

Should you change your mind, at the end of our tour and set ups, I will guide you on how to find the credit card conversation that will walk you through the process of adding credit cards.
Alright, let’s get started and take control of your budget together!

<<Accounts>>

Let's start by giving your budget a name.

Choosing your budget's name is a simple yet important step. It should reflect your aspirations and give you a sense of motivation every time you see it. 

Here are a few examples to get you started: My Money Plan, My Calm Spending Plan, My Savvy Spending Plan, Plan to Freedom, Plan to Debt-Free.

<<Accounts>>

As you are just starting out, I recommend taking the manual route. This will not only save you some bucks but also help you develop the habit of actively engaging with your money and spending habits.

You can always set up a bank sync later on.

Ready to proceed with manual input?

<<Accounts>>

Of course! I want to note that credit cards should be used strategically and not for continuous spending. They can be great tools for maintaining a healthy credit score if used wisely. 

However, relying on them for day-to-day expenses can lead you into a deep hole.

<<Accounts>>

If you are interested in adding credit card accounts, click on 'Start a New Conversation' above 'Schedule Video Call' on the left-hand side. 

Then select 'Add Credit Card'. A new convo will pop up to guide you through the process
of adding your credit cards.

<<Accounts>>

No problemo, you don't have to add your credit cards to MBC, but I want to note that credit cards should be used strategically and not for continuous spending. 

They can be great tools for maintaining a healthy credit score if used wisely. However, relying on them for day-to-day expenses can lead you into deep hole.

<<Accounts>>

That's amazing! 🎉 Kudos to you for not using credit cards. This can help you avoid unnecessary debt and financial strain. Keep up the great work!

<<Accounts>>

Once you confirm a transaction has cleared your bank, you can update and mark it as completed in MBC by selecting the check mark to turn it green.

This will keep your spending picture up to date.

<<Accounts>>


Note: The 'Undo' and 'Redo' buttons are also available in the Budget screen. 

However, when selected, they will 'Undo' or 'Redo' your last action completed for either Accounts or Budget, depending on where your last action was.
Link to giphy: https://giphy.com/gifs/abcnetwork-abc-home-economics-homeeconomics-IVcQCXV2CYRdtncxaq

<<Budget>>

 If you're a planner like me and enjoy preparing for what may come ahead, it's helpful to be able to view a few months out.

However, be careful not to plan too far ahead and lose track of your current financial reality.

<<Budget>>

You now get to decide how much of the $500 you want to put in each envelope.

 And, when you want to make a purchase or payment, you take money from the right envelope.

If the envelope is empty, it means you can't buy more of that thing until you replenish the envelope.
I'm following!

<<Budget>>

So, you get a few envelopes and write the names of different things you need and want to spend money on. For example, you might have an envelope for snacks, gas, or a phone bill.

<<Budget>>

If I see that my Coffee Trip envelope is low or empty, I now have to decide whether I want to hold onto what's left or I have to wait to fill it up again.

<<Budget>>

The cash envelope system is a simple way to see exactly where your money is going and make sure you don't run out too fast. With MyBudgetCoach we are doing this digitally.
My budget is set up!

<<Budget>>

Be sure to add in your savings goals and how much you'd like to contribute each month.

You do not have to deposit the same amount of money every month if it is not feasible.

<<Budget>>

Tracking them separately helps you know exactly where your money is going and helps you prioritize if you have to make decisions. 

To recap, bills are like the must-pay stuff, while expenses are more flexible.
move_to: budgeted_column

<<Budget>>

Awesome! Now that you've seen how to move money around, let's start putting your money to work. 

Remember that the goal is to give every dollar a job, so try not to leave any money in the 'To Budget' bucket.

<<Budget>>

Reminder: Accidents happen and you're allowed to change your mind, so use the 'undo' and 'redo' buttons if needed.

I've been super grateful for them when I've accidentally deleted something.

<<Budget>>

As you start to use your budget table and enter your transactions, you may notice numbers start to show in your Balance column.

<<Budget>>

If you see $0.00 in the balance column, that means you have not budgeted for or spent in that specific column.

<<Budget>>

If you see a positive black number, that is a good thing. This means you have not spent anything in that category yet, or if you have, you've stayed within your budget and have the remaining balance left over

<<Budget>>

You can cover the overspending by pulling from another category. 

1. Click on the negative red number
2. Click 'Cover overspending'
3. Select an envelope (budget category) to choose from.

Note: You can not pull from another category that does not have an available balance.

<<Accounts>>

If you find yourself using credit cards like a debit card, reach out to me so we can discuss effective strategies for managing your credit card use.

<<Accounts>>


If you find yourself using your credit cards like a debit card, reach out to me so we can discuss effective strategies for managing your credit card use.
Good-bye for now!
If at any time you'd like to reset our conversation, you can do so by clicking the purple 'Manage Coach' button and then click on 'Reset Coach'.

When I'm not budgeting or helping others with their budgets, I love instructing and participating in Zumba classes, taking long walks, watching thriller movies, reading self-improvement books, and discovering creative ways to make extra money.

What are some things you love spending money on? It could be anything from your favorite coffee or a hobby you enjoy.

Considering this will help you understand your priorities and find ways to incorporate them into your budget.

You're here because you want to make the most of your money without feeling restricted. And, I totally get that. I'll show you that budgeting doesn't have to feel like a diet. It can actually be fun! 

You can spend your money how you want on the things you love as long you plan and prioritize accordingly.

Before we dive in, let's break the ice a bit.

<<Accounts>>

To rename your budget:
  1. Click on the down arrow.
  2. Select "Rename Budget".
  3. Type in your budget's new name.
  4. Click "Enter".
If you ever want to change the name later on, you can always come back and update it.
move_to: budget_name

<<Accounts>>

I also find this feature useful for tracking whether automatic payments I expected to come out were processed correctly.

<<Budget>>

 If you tend to overspend, consider setting short-term financial goals alongside your monthly budget. These goals can help you stay focused on your current priorities while gradually improving your spending habits.

<<Budget>>
 
If you find yourself consistently overspending in certain categories, the next steps are to:
1. Review your budget
2. Identify spending triggers
3. Prioritize essentials

The ultimate goal is to avoid the risk of over-drafting your checking account or adding debt to your credit card.

Thanks for selecting the Add Credit Card conversation!

This conversation walks through the steps for how to add a credit card account. Whether you are a new MyBudgetCoach user, or a long-term user that now needs to add a credit card account, this conversation is meant for you.

<<Accounts>>

Please login to your bank so you can gather your current credit card balance.
highlight: zoom_link

<<Accounts>>

Before we link a third credit card account, let me ask a follow-up question.
highlight: add_account

<<Budget>>

Because you can pay the balance in-full, and have a credit card category with a 'Balance' = 0, moving forward with your MyBudgetCoach use, you will be funding your categories outside of the credit card category. If you aren't accumulating any debt, have covered any overspent categories, then your credit card payment will be equal to your current balance.
highlight: add_account

For the credit card account(s) you added, are there any that you plan to pay off the current balance at the end of this month?

Please note, by 'current balance' I am referring to the balance you entered when you added the account. This is not the statement balance, which is a balance as of an earlier date.
Add later: You can complete the 'Calculate Credit Card Payment' conversation at any time to assist in determining what your credit card payment should be.

<<Accounts>>

Please login to your bank so you can gather your current credit card balance.

<<Budget>>

Give yourself some grace and remember, reducing your debt is a journey and takes dedication. You already have started working toward your goal by using this budgeting software and working through this conversation to learn more!

<<Budget>>

If you have more than one credit card account, you will need to complete the following steps for each account.

<<Budget>>

Step 1 is to create a Category Group called 'Credit Cards.' Under that Category Group, you would add a Category for each of the credit card account(s) you added.

Let me add this for you as a starting point...

<<Budget>>

OK! Step 1 is completed. Please scroll down to the bottom of your budget table to find the Credit Card category group and rename the newly created category to your specific credit card account name.

create_category_group: Credit Cards
create_category: Credit Cards: Credit Card Account

<<Accounts>>

The first transaction should be the transaction that was added when you first added the account. You should see an amount in the 'Payment' column that equals the balance on the day you added the account.

<<Accounts>>

Now that we have created the category on the Budget for the Credit Card Account, we are going to change the Category from 'Starting Balance' to the newly created category for your Credit Card Account.
Great work! Now, lets go back to the Budget and see what happened with the 'Spent' and 'Balance' columns in the Credit Card Account category.

<<Budget>>

Scroll down to the credit card category of the account you just updated. Now the 'Spent' column is a negative number that equals your balance you entered previously.

<<Budget>>

Since the 'Budgeted' column for the category is 0, the 'Balance' is a negative red number and is equal to 'Spent.'
highlight: spent_column

<<Budget>>

The last step, Step 3, is to complete the actions for how you want MyBudgetCoach to handle the debt associated with the credit card. You have some options, so let me first ask you a question so I can tailor my guidance.

<<Budget>>

Good for you! KUDOS on managing your debt. Very few people with a credit card balance have the cash flow to pay in-full at any time.

<<Budget>>

To fund your balance you enter the amount of your credit card balance in the Budgeted column of your newly created credit card category. This will update the 'Balance' to be 0 since you budgeted dollars to equal the current balance of the credit card.

<<Budget>>

When you Budgeted the dollars, the purple number at the top of the Budget Summary in the 'To Budget' went down.

<<Budget>>

You can now budget with confidence the rest of your available dollars to your remaining categories, until your 'To Budget' number is 0.

<<Budget>>

We need to allow the remaining balance you don't pay off this current month, to continue to future months, since your credit card company will continue to have that balance carry over until you pay it off.

<<Budget>>

MyBudgetCoach has a unique feature that is called 'Rollover overspending.' This option allows a user to have the debt continue into future months, instead of paying off this month, so you can pay it off overtime.

<<Budget>>

Selecting the 'Rollover overspending' option increases your 'To Budget' number in the current month, since the debt has now been rolled over to future months.

<<Budget>>

Select the negative amount in red text in the Balance column of your Credit Card Account Category. Within the option menu that comes up, select the 'Rollover overspending' option.

To see the system roll the debt over to a future month, select the option in the top left to show two months at a time by selecting the 2nd calendar icon.

<<Budget>>

Great catch! That is correct. The arrow to the right of the amount in the Balance column is how MyBudgetCoach alerts you to the fact you have rolled over the overspending for future months. This option will stay turned on for all future months, unless you select to 'Remove overspending rollover.'

<<Budget>>

When you budget to the category it reduces the debt immediately. You'll still have to submit a payment through your credit card account, but you can see your progress in the category right away.

<<Budget>>

To handle interest applied to your credit card account(s), if applicable, you would categorize that transaction to the Category of your Credit Card Account, just like how you updated the Starting Balance category.

<<Budget>>

Credit Cards can be complex, especially if you have more than one credit card account. I am available for a one-on-one call at your convenience to help answer any questions you may have in your future use of MyBudgetCoach.

<<Accounts>>

The important difference between a bank account and a credit card account is that for a credit card account, Payments INCREASE the balance, and Deposits DECREASE the balance. This is because a credit card balance is negative.

<<Accounts>>

Please select your main credit card account. You will now add two hypothetical transactions.

<<Accounts>>

Please select '+ Add New,' select today's date and enter a Payee of 'Cell Phone Company.'

<<Accounts>>

Select an applicable category and enter a Payment amount of 100, Clear the transaction, and select Add.

<<Accounts>>

Let's now add a transaction for a credit card payment. Credit Card payments are Transfers and entered as a Deposit.

<<Accounts>>

The credit card balance, a red negative number, has now increased by 100.

<<Accounts>>

Please select '+ Add New,' select today's date, and for the Payee, select 'Make Transfer.' Within the 'Transfer To/From' list of accounts, select your checking account.

<<Accounts>>

The Category field is now populated with Transfer. Enter 100 in the 'Deposit' field, since this is a payment to reduce the credit card balance, and select Add.

<<Accounts>>

Let's now jump over to the checking account.

<<Accounts>>

Since you selected 'Make Transfer' as the Payee in your credit card account, this automatically added a transaction to your checking account as well.

<<Accounts>>

Please take note that the credit card payment is an outflow in the Payment column for the checking account, but an inflow in the Deposit column for the credit card. This is because your payment reduces a negative balance (Deposit) in the credit card account and reduces the positive balance (Payment) in the checking account.

<<Accounts>>

Kudos on creating transactions for both accounts! 🎉

<<Accounts>>

Before we move to the next step, let's delete those two credit card transactions you added.

<<Accounts>>

Please navigate back to your main credit card account and select each of the two transactions using the box to the left of the date. Then select the link named '2 transactions' to the right of the search bar and choose Delete.

Happy budgeting!

Budget Table Overview

<<Budget>>

This is the budget table, basically a digital cash envelope system! You create categories relevant to your life and budget dollars accordingly.

<<Budget>>

The Category column houses the names of each category. We'll get customizing these in a bit.

<<Budget>>

The Budgeted column is where you'll be budgeting your dollars. This shows you what you have allocated each month for the categories.

<<Budget>>

Next up is the Spent column. This shows you what you've actually spent out of the budgeted dollars.

<<Budget>>

The last column is Balance. This shows you what you have available to spend. If it's negative and red, you've overspent in this category. If the amount is black, that's what you have available.

<<Budget>>

If you don't cover this overspending, you either risk over-drafting your checking account or adding debt to your credit card.

<<Budget>>

To the left of the header 'Category' at the top of the Budget Table, select the three dots. This gives you visual options. You can show and hide hidden categories and collapse or expand Category Groups.

<<Budget>>

When you hover over a row, an arrow appears. The rows in 'Grey' that have bold text are called 'Category Groups.' The arrow in a Category Group row has options to add a category in this group, hide it, rename it or delete it.

<<Budget>>

Now, add a category to this group. Choose a regular monthly bill you pay, such as your cell phone.

<<Budget>>

For checking account transactions, payments DECREASE the balance and deposits INCREASE the balance.

<<Accounts>> / <<Budget>>

This aligns the avatar with which screen the user should be on. If a user goes to the Budget at a step where the avatar flow has <<Accounts>>, or if the user goes to an Account while the avatar is on Budget, the user will see the following message:

 Please navigate to the Accounts {Budget} to continue our conversation (please select an account).

Please Note: There needs to be a blank line between the reference to Accounts/Budget and the text shown in the avatar window.
Trusting Your Numbers

One of the complexities for users with a zero-based budgeting software is the due diligence to ensure the account balances in MyBudgetCoach match the account balances in the financial institution. 

A difficult part of having the accounts match is ensuring the starting balance set by the user at the time the accounts are added are accurate. For checking accounts, some banks include pending transactions in the Current Balance. If the starting balance includes pending transactions, then when the transactions are added, they will be double counted. For credit cards, the Current Balance doesn't include pending transactions, so this is not an issue. 

Coach can consider consulting Coach Trainers to add a flow for verifying starting balance.
...one last thing before I leave you to your budgeting...

People who have Credit Card balances in excess of their available dollars in their checking account will have a negative amount To Budgeted. This is an important step for the user, but can be handled in a various number of ways. Consider the main steps the user needs to complete, and then determine as the coach if you want to add more detail for any of those steps:

1) Adding the Credit Card Category Group
2) Add a Category for each Credit Card
3) Changing the category on the account side of the Credit Card starting balance to the newly created Category
4) Rollover overspending if not going to pay off balance

This will give the user back their dollars in their checking account in the To Budgeted.

Budget Setup

You as the Coach can do as much or as little as you would like for the user. For example, if you just want to add a handful of categories, or walk them through how to edit and add themselves, that is fine. Alternatively, you could have the system build an entire budget with defined groups, and categories, so when they select the button before the template is built, it automatically updates.

Some coaches have built the table in phases, others offer the option of just groups, and the user adds categories, or the user adds everything. Full discretion to the coach!

<<Budget>>

Text to celebrate the budget table being updated

<<Budget>>

Prepare user for when they select an option, the template will be updated automatically.

<<Budget>>

Wrap-up setup

<<Budget>>

How to move money

Select the To Budget number; Enter amount into Budgeted column; Select amount in Balance and choose Transfer to another category

<<Budget>>

Tips on prioritizing Budgeting dollars so all dollars are budgeted

If starting in middle of month or end of month, remind user to not Budget for dollars already spent, or they don't need. For example, don't budget your entire month of groceries if you only have 10 days left in the month.

What kind of device?

Consider asking a user what type of device they are using. If using a computer, the current language for how to access options works. If using a tablet, somethings are different (tap versus hover; double click versus single click...). Can utilize the IF syntax to adjust the response in a box where overviewing how to use software dependent on the device the user has.

Buttons default to 'Next' if no text is added on line. Button text can be short, or long (even two sentences) and include emojis. If have multiple lines due to a question, can program button text for each line.
Consider having a question to create a break for the user. Could also reference the earlier list of steps to complete, and show progress by crossing out those pieces that are done.
Additional Conversations
Simple FIN

MyBudgetCoach has a direct import option. A coach can either walk through in detail how to complete this, or they can create a separate conversation for if a user to click through at a later point if interested.

Accounts can be linked at any time, so if added manually, can then link for direct import later on.

Linking direct import immediately can be helpful as SimpleFIN's connection will automatically set the starting balance. But the process takes some time and for a new user, they may want to make progress on the software itself and not spend 10-15 minutes just setting up direct import. 

Could always recommend they delete prior accounts, and add new ones once SimpleFIN is linked. This first budget is just a test to get started. Set up real budget with your actual accounts and setting up.

Button Text

<<Accounts>>

The 'Undo' and 'Redo' buttons are helpful tools when you are working in this screen.

Please note: These are also available in the Budget screen as well. However, when selected, they will 'Undo' or 'Redo' your last action completed for either Accounts or Budget, depending on where your last action was.

<<Accounts>>

This is the 'Search' bar. As you type, whether text or numbers, the list of transactions will dynamically filter down based on criteria entered.
move_to: search_bar

<<Accounts>>

This is the 'Split/Toggle' button. If you happen to have split transactions, this button will expand or collapse those transactions from view.
move_to: split_toggle_button
Button Text

<<Accounts>>

These three dots show additional options.

<<Accounts>>

1. Show running balance
2. Hide 'cleared' checkboxes
3. Export
4. Reconcile
5. Link account
6. Close account
move_to: more_button
Coach can decide how much explanation they want to provide for each of these. Reconciliation for example can be a complex discussion.

<<Accounts>>

Type "Cell Phone Company" as your Payee.
move_to: select_payee
move_to: select_category

<<Accounts>>

Now, enter $100 in the Payment box.
move_to: payment_input

<<Accounts>>

Now click "Add". 

Please note, you can select "Cancel" to get out of adding transactions.
move_to: cleared_status_icon
move_to: save_transaction
move_to: months_band
move_to: budget_table
move_to: category_column
move_to: budgeted_column
move_to: spent_column
move_to: balance_column

<<Budget>>

The rows below a Category Group row, not shaded grey and not bold text, are called Categories. When you hover over a Category row, the arrow that appears gives you the option to Hide, Rename, and Delete that Category.
Button Text

<<Budget>>

Below the categories is the 'Income' Section.

<<Budget>>

The Income row is the total amount of deposits to a checking or savings account in a month. 

The Starting Balances row is calculated your first month, but then remains $0 each month after that. You can 'Hide' this category if you choose after your first month.
move_to: received_column

<<Budget>>

Also when you hover on a Category row, a small paper icon appears. Selecting this opens up a note box. This can be used to capture helpful information about that category. For example, the amount you intend to budget each month, or when it is due, if not due monthly.
Button Text

<<Budget>>

When you hover over the month at the top of the budget summary, two up arrows are shown to the left. Selecting this will collapse the budget summary view to only show the 'To Budget' amount.

You can expand by hovering over the month and then selecting the two now down arrows to the left of the month.

<<Budget>>

To the right of the month there are three vertical dots. Selecting this shows additional options that can have dollars budgeted to all your categories in one click.

<<Budget>>

These options include:

1. Copy last month's budget
2. Set budgets to zero
3. Set budgets to 3 month average
highlight: budget_more_button

All boxes don't need to have <<Accounts>> or <<Budget>>. If you remove this, that means the user can be in either screen and the avatar will continue. This can help with transitions from one section to another.

<<Budget>>

Let's move now to how to go about budgeting your dollars and how to give every dollar a job!
Button Text

<<Budget>>

Great job on understanding how to use the Budget! Before we wrap-up, there is probably one topic you have been wondering about: Credit Cards.

<<Budget>>

Let's flip over to the account screen to talk through this.
This section could be very extensive, or you could keep it high level and create a separate conversation the next time the user gets paid.
Button Text

<<Accounts>>

Part 1 of the credit cards overview is completed. Now for part 2, editing the Budget Table for the credit card.

<<Accounts>>

Instruct user to flip over to Budget to add Categories for each of their cards.

Consider asking the user the question if they are planning to pay off the current balance (not the statement balance) in-full.
Credit Card wrap-up; Move to wrap-up and good-bye of introduction avatar.

<<Accounts>>

This section is split into two parts:

1) Adding account(s), test transaction, and payments.
2) Budget updates

First off, let's check if you have any credit card accounts.

<<Accounts>>

Click "+ Add New" and select today's date.
move_to: add_new_button

<<Accounts>>

For the category, select the appropriate category from your budget table. You can start typing the category name and have the list of available categories filter down.

<<Accounts>>

Finish this transaction by selecting the check mark to turn it green.

<<Accounts>>

Notice the account balance has increased by $75.
move_to: account_balance

<<Accounts>>

Type "Grocery Store" as your Payee.
move_to: select_payee
move_to: select_category

<<Accounts>>

Now, enter $75 in the Payment box.
move_to: payment_input

<<Accounts>>

Now click "Add". 

Please note, you can select "Cancel" to get out of adding transactions.
move_to: cleared_status_icon
move_to: save_transaction
Button Text

<<Accounts>>

Explain the inverse relationship with credit cards vs bank accounts. Payments increase the balance, Deposits decrease the balance. This is because credit cards are negative balances so the inverse occurs.

<<Accounts>>

Let's delete this pretend transaction. Go ahead and hover on the left side of the date to un-hide a box. Select the box to select the transaction.
Button Text

<<Accounts>>

Introduce how to add a transfer transaction. For example, making a payment to a credit card.

<<Accounts>>

Explain the sections of a transfer: Select 'Transfer To / From' in the Payee; no Category; transaction automatically added in other account.

<<Accounts>>

To the right hand side of the search box, select the purple text with '1 transaction' to see a series of options.

Select 'Delete' to remove that transaction.
Could ask the user if they have more than one card. Could limit to just one or two they use most frequently.
Could ask the user if they plan to pay off card in-full. If they do, don't need to complete the steps. If they don't, steps are important.
Could ask the user if they see a negative Red Overbudgeted number, or if it is less than they expected.
move_to: selected_transactions_button
